lines.text: Ladies don't start fights, but they can finish them!
Lafayette! Lafayette, listen.
Oh, shucks, Napoleon. That ain't nothin' more but a little ol' cricket bug.
It's squeaky shoes approachin'.
Oh, cricket bugs don't wear shoes.
Hush your mouth! Let's see. They're Oxford shoes, size nine and a half. Hole in the left sole, it sounds like.
What color are they?
Why, they're black... Ah, now how would I know that?
Me first! Me first!
Why should you be first?
Because I'm a lady. That's why.
Oh, you're not a lady.
You're nothing but a sister!
It's a motorcycle. Two cylinder. Chain drive. One squeaky wheel, on the front, it sounds like. Now you go for the tires, and I'll go right for the seat of the problem.
How come you always grab the tender part for yourself?
'Cause I outrank you, that's why. Now, stop beatin' your gums and sound the attack.
[Lafayette barks]
No, that's mess call.
Made a mess of it, huh?
You can be replaced, you know.
Why, your eyes are like sapphires sparkling so bright. They make the morning radiant and light.
How romantic.
Sissy stuff.
Oh, c'est très jolie, monsieur. Very poetic. But it is not quite Shakespeare.
'Course not. That's pure O'Malley, baby. Right off the cuff. Yeah. I got a million of 'em.
It's outrageous! Why, you won't believe what they tried to do to your poor Uncle Waldo. Look! Look at this!
[reading from menu of Le Petit Cafe]
"Prime Country Goose A la Provencale, stuffed with chestnuts"...? "And basted in white wine." Hic!
Basted? He's been marinated in it.
Dreadful! Being British, I would've preferred sherry.
I am Amelia Gabble. And this is my sister.
Abigail Gabble.
We're twin sisters.
In fact, you could say we're related.
Your husband is very charming and very handsome.
Well, you see, I'm not exactly her husband.
Exactly? Either you are or you're not.
All right. I'm not.
Oh?
He's scandalous.
Indeed
He's absolutely positively a reprobate.
A roue.
His eyes are too close together.
Very shifty, too.
And look at his crooked smile!
His chin is very weak, too.
Obviously a philanderer who triffles with unsuspecting women's hearts.
How romantic.
Okay, let's charge!
Wait a minute. I'm the leader! I'm the one that says when we go.
[pause]
Here we go. Charge!
[Berlioz has been scared by a frog]
Oh, darling. That's only a little frog, my love.
But he had a mouth like a "hippolotamus."
What's a little swinger like you doing on our side of town?
Please! I was sent for help, by a cat.
Why that's outrageous! It's crazy!
[cats laugh]
But honest! He said just to mention his name.
So, start mentioning name, rodent.
Now, don't rush me, fellas. His name is... O'Toole.
I don't dig him. Strike one.
O'Brian?
Strike two.
Oh boy... You believe me, don't you?
Keep talkin', Mousey.
How about... O'... Grady?

[reveals a claw]
Mousey, you've just struck out.
[Holds it close to him]
Any last words?

[looks terrified, then frustrated]
Oh, why did I ever listen to that O'Malley cat?
O'Malley?
O'Malley?
O'Malley?
Hold it, cats! This little guy's on the level.
You're darn tootin' I'm on the level!
We didn't mean-a to ruff-a ya, squeaky!
Don't worry about me, O'Malley needs help, Duchess and the kittens are in trouble!
[All the cats then start running out of the alley]
Come on, cats! We gotta split!
[last lines]
Hey, Napoleon. That sounds like the end.
Wait a minute. I'm the leader, I say when it's the end.
[the title "The End" bumps into Napoleon's head]
It's the end.
[Edgar is listening in on Madame discussing her will]
As you know, I have no living relatives, and I want my cats to be well taken care of. And who can do that better than my faithful servant, Edgar?
Edgar? Adelaide, you mean you're giving your vast fortune to Edgar?All your stocks and bonds, this-this mansion, your country chateau, your jewels and gems...?
No, no, no, George. To my cats.
To your cats?

[gasping]
Cats?
Yes. I just wish for the cats to inherit first. Then at the end of their life span, the entire estate reverts to Edgar.
Cats inherit first, and I come after the cats! After I... oh. It's not fair!
[Stands up, hits head on intercom]

Ooh! I mean, each cat will live about twelve years, I can't wait... and each cat has nine lives! That's four times twelve, times nine... No, it's less than that. Anyway, that's more than I'll ever live. I'll be gone! No, oh, no. They'll be gone. I'll think of a way. After all, there are millions of reasons why I should. All of them dollars. Millions. Those cats have got to go!

[listening]
You're not gonna believe this, but it's a one wheel hay stack!
You know something? I like Uncle Waldo.

[laughs]
Especially when he's marinated.
Thomas, this is Amelia and Abigail Gabble.
Yeah, honey. Get those two web-footed lifeguards out of here.
Now, now, Thomas.
Okay. Okay, baby.
[to the geese]
Hiya, chicks.
[Abigail and Amelia Gabble laugh]
We're not chickens. We're geese.

[sarcastically]
No. I thought you were swans.
Come on, Edgar. Last one upstairs is a nincompoop.
Could we take the elevator this time, sir?
That birdcage? Poppycock! Elevators are for old people. Whoops!
[Hautecourt almost falls back, Edgar catches him]
May I give you a hand, sir?
You wouldn't have an extra foot, would you, Edgar?
Amelia, if I walk any further, I'll get flat feet.
Abigail, we were born with flat feet.

[singing]
Everybody wants to be a cat / Because a cat's the only cat who knows where it's at.
Tell me! Everyone is picking up on that feline beat / 'Cause everything else is obsolete.
Strictly high-buttoned shoes.

[Sitting on the piano]
I'm ready, Maestro.
[Berlioz slides on the keys, and Marie's tail is pinched]
Ow! Mama, he did it again!
Tattletale.
Now the squeaking has stopped.
I still say it was a little ol' cricket bug.
Wait a minute. I'm the leader. I decide what it was.
[pause]
It was a little ol' cricket bug.
Here you go, small fry. Blow it.
[Berlioz blows hard on a trumpet playing a very sour note]
Boy, he blew it!
[chuckles]
But he was close.
Boy! Your eyes *are* like sapphires.
Berlioz, come back here. Haven't you forgotten something, darling?
Thank you, Miss Frou-Frou, for letting me ride on your back.
You're quite welcome, young man.
[Berlioz turns to his mama]
How was that, Mama?
Very good, darling. That was very nice.
We were just practicing biting and clawing.
Aristocats do not practice biting and clawing, and things like that. It's just horrible.
But someday, we might meet a tough alley cat.
That's quite a family. Come to think of it, O'Malley, you're not a cat, you're a rat. Right? Right.

[Trips and almost falls]
Whoops! Not as spry as I was when I was eighty.
Monsieur O'Malley, you could have lost your life.
So I have a few to spare. Nothing.

[instructing the cats on how to walk]
Now, think goose.
[Edgar tries to grab his hat from off of Napoleon's head, but it lands on Lafayette]

[grabbing the hat]
That's *my* hat! I'm the leader!
[puts it back on his head]
Well, shoot fire! Don't get sore at me! I ain't done nothing!
Where's my hat? Where? And somebody stole my bumbershoot!
Well, where's my beddy-bye basket?
And whoever it is, is gonna get it and get it good!
And this time, *I* get the tender part.
Hush your mouth! Now come on!
Now, girls, don't go shooshing your old Uncle Waldo! Why, you'll wake up the whole neighborhood!
[shouts]
Whoopee!
[Berlioz compares an unsightly painting to Edgar and laughs]
Now, Berlioz, that is not kind. You know Edgar is so fond of us, and takes very good care of us.
[Cut to Edgar emptying a bottle of sleeping pills into the cats' milk while singing to himself]
Aloha, auf Wiedersehen, bon soir, sayonara, and all those good bye things, baby.
Humans don't really worry too much about their pets.
Morning, Frou-Frou, my pretty steed.
[whispers]
Can you keep a secret?
[out loud]
Of course you can.
[chuckles]
I've some news straight from the horse's mouth. If you'll pardon the expression, of course.
First, to make the magic begin, you wiggle your nose, and you tickle your chin. Now close your eyes, and cross your heart, and presto! - breakfast, à la carte.
Oh boy, fellas! Let's rock the joint!
Ha, ha! Groovy cats!
I told you it was Edgar.
Aw, shut up, Toulouse.
Birds of a feather must *hic* together!

[his last words]
You're going to Timbuktu if it's the last thing I do.
Shang-hai Hong Kong egg fu yung! Fortune cookie always wrong!
Shanghai, Hong Kong, Egg foo young / Fortune cookie always wrong. Oh, that a hot one!
